text.headline: The Evolution of Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence
text.text: A journey through the key milestones that shaped modern AI and ML

text.headline: First Neural Network Model
text.text: Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts created the first mathematical model of a neural network, laying the foundation for artificial neural networks.

text.headline: The Turing Test
text.text: Alan Turing proposed the famous Turing Test in his paper 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence', establishing a benchmark for machine intelligence.

text.headline: Birth of Artificial Intelligence
text.text: The Dartmouth Conference, organized by John McCarthy, coined the term 'Artificial Intelligence' and established AI as a field of study.

media.caption: The Dartmouth Conference marked the beginning of AI

text.headline: The Perceptron
text.text: Frank Rosenblatt developed the Perceptron, the first algorithm capable of learning from data through supervised learning.

text.headline: First AI Winter Begins
text.text: Due to overhyped expectations and limited computing power, funding for AI research decreased significantly, marking the first 'AI Winter'.

media.caption: The challenges of early AI development

text.headline: Backpropagation Concept
text.text: While not fully developed until the 1980s, the mathematical foundations for backpropagation were being established, crucial for training neural networks.

text.headline: Expert Systems Era
text.text: Expert systems became popular, using rule-based reasoning to solve complex problems in specific domains like medical diagnosis.

text.headline: Backpropagation Algorithm
text.text: Rumelhart, Hinton, and Williams popularized the backpropagation algorithm, revolutionizing how neural networks could learn complex patterns.

text.headline: Support Vector Machines
text.text: Vladimir Vapnik introduced Support Vector Machines, providing a powerful method for classification and regression tasks.

text.headline: Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov
text.text: IBM's Deep Blue became the first computer to defeat a world chess champion in a match, marking a significant milestone in AI capabilities.

text.headline: Random Forest Algorithm
text.text: Leo Breiman introduced Random Forest, an ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees for improved accuracy.

text.headline: Deep Learning Renaissance
text.text: Geoffrey Hinton's work on deep belief networks sparked renewed interest in neural networks, beginning the deep learning revolution.

text.headline: AlexNet and ImageNet
text.text: Alex Krizhevsky's AlexNet won the ImageNet competition by a large margin, demonstrating the power of deep convolutional neural networks.

text.headline: Generative Adversarial Networks
text.text: Ian Goodfellow introduced GANs, enabling machines to generate realistic data by training two neural networks against each other.

text.headline: AlphaGo Defeats Lee Sedol
text.text: DeepMind's AlphaGo defeated world champion Lee Sedol in Go, a game previously thought too complex for AI to master.

text.headline: Transformer Architecture
text.text: The 'Attention Is All You Need' paper introduced the Transformer architecture, revolutionizing natural language processing.

text.headline: BERT and Language Models
text.text: Google introduced BERT, demonstrating how pre-trained language models could achieve state-of-the-art results across many NLP tasks.

text.headline: GPT-3 and Large Language Models
text.text: OpenAI released GPT-3 with 175 billion parameters, showcasing the capabilities of large-scale language models in various tasks.

media.caption: The era of large language models

text.headline: ChatGPT and AI Mainstream
text.text: OpenAI's ChatGPT brought AI to the mainstream, demonstrating conversational AI capabilities to millions of users worldwide.

text.headline: Multimodal AI and GPT-4
text.text: The release of GPT-4 and other multimodal models marked a new era where AI can understand and generate text, images, and other media types.
